text.p: UK-based air management company AirRep said from April 1 to July 14 it flew 22,539 refugees on 110 flights from the Congo Democratic Republic (formerly Zaire) back to Rwanda for the UNHCR.

Managing director Colin Martin told Reuters in a telephone interview that during the same period it had flown 1,251,150 kg of aid from Entebbe to Kigali for the UNHCR -- the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

He added that about 15,000 further refugees considered healthy enough to fly -- out of a total of some 20,000 remaining in President Laurent Kabila's Congo -- would start to be transported by AirLift and other carriers from the country to Kigali over a 10-15 day period starting on Monday.

The cargo shipments, said Martin, had included tents, medicines, hospital units, vehicles and related aid equipment and were flown on 42-tonne capacity Ilyushin IL-76 freighters operated by AirRep management client Latvia, the Latvian cargo airline.
He said that AirRep had been responsible for flying refugees from Kisingani, Kinshasa, Mbuji-Mayi and Mbandaka in the former Zaire and from Brazzaville in the Congo Republic to Rwanda.
